discussion.content: Layer 6 Presentation Layer for formatting such as JPEG, XML etc.

comments.content: Layer 7 defines the process that enables applications to use network services. XML and JSON are not applications, so it can't be Layer 7.

discussion.content: I think that this is layer 7

comments.content: No, it is Presentation layer (6). Presentation layer involves decoding/translating data types like xml and JSON. https://osi-model.com/presentation-layer/

questions.question_text: A content filter is set to analyze XML and JSON that users access from the Internet. At which of the following layers is this analysis taking place?

discussion.content: VLAN mismatch is caused by a switch configured incorrectly. Duplex/speed mismatch will cause collisions, slowing down the network. The other options does fit the question. So, the answer is B
The key phrase here is: "cannot print to any of the printers in the department or access any of the resources that others can." These symptoms are typical of a VLAN mismatch.

I have tried to look for a word or words that would give a clue that a VLAN mismatch was causing the problem. Upon research, I did find what a VLAN mismatch would do to the network communications. Can someone add their input on this question?

comments.content: Anne is 'new to the dept' meaning she previously had access to the internet and internal resources needed for her old position. Her old VLAN can still access the interwebs but wouldn't be configured to communicate with the new local/internal services of her new position.

Take the VLAN out of the question for now, you have network A the rest of the department your on this network, instead your placed into the port of network B, you can get out to the internet but do nothing else, bring back in the VLAN now and imagine the device is placed in the wrong port on a switch, placing it in network B

questions.question_text: Ann, a new employee within a department, cannot print to any of the printers in the department or access any of the resources that others can. However, she can access the Internet. The network engineer has confirmed that Ann's account has been set up the same as the others. There are no access lists restricting Ann's access. Which of the following could be the issue for this lack of access?

choices.A: Perform a DNS lookup on the server.
choices.B: Set up an SSH session to the desktop.
choices.C: Reference the ARP table in the router.
choices.D: Configure port security on the switch.

comments.content: Now that you mentioned Switch I am really confused. "C. Reference the ARP table in the router." Could it be because ARP works between Layers 2 and 3 and you can find them in both Router and Swicth?

discussion.content: Each switch has an ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) table to store the IP addresses and MAC addresses of the network devices. The ARP table is used to determine the destination MAC addresses of the network nodes, as well as the VLANs and ports from where the nodes are reached.

comments.content: Now it makes more sense.. I knew only for first part.
The ARP table is used to determine the destination MAC addresses of the network nodes, as well as the VLANs and ports from where the nodes are reached. The second part is not mentioned often.

discussion.content: anyone know why the answer is C please?

questions.question_text: A technician is configuring a printer for a client. The technician connects the printer to the network, but is unsure how to determine its switchport. Which of the following should the technician do FIRST to locate the switchport?
A router is set up to utilize RIPv2 to route traffic throughout the network. Which of the following routing metrics is used to determine the path?

discussion.content: Damn, I did not think this one through. I selected distance. Metrics used to determine the distance are the number of hops.
Rip and Ripv2 ALWAYS has to do with hop count
yep distance vector routing does not mean actual distance, but rather the quantity of hops

"A second router was installed on a network to be used as a backup for the primary router" 
When you have two routers that are doing the same thing, you want to use a virtual IP that they would swap off on.
Reserved IP is a DHCP concept. You wouldn't assign a router an address with DHCP.

questions.question_text: A second router was installed on a network to be used as a backup for the primary router that works as a gateway. The infrastructure team does not want to change the IP address of the gateway on the devices. Which of the following network components should be used in this scenario?
